##Interview with Wang Guangfa: Rapid diagnosis is an urgent matter

Wechat, renwumag1980

Feature Introduction, the best Chinese character report

Wang was interviewed by people on the evening of Feb. 3, the fourth day after he recovered from COVID-19 pneumonia and the second day after returning to work at the hospital. As head of the Peking University First Hospital, he was initially cautious, saying he did not want to be interviewed again, but he was willing to talk to me about technical issues. He was willing to share his understanding of the sudden onset of the disease as a respiratory therapist, as well as a patient who had experienced COVID-19 pneumonia, as if facing an unknown Emerging Infectious Diseases, how do we recognize it, understand it, and deal with it? What is the scientific response?

Therefore, the writing of this article is also special. In this dialogue, we retain a large number of professor Wang Guangfa referred to the clinical experience, operational recommendations, diagnostic thinking. This may be tedious for non-medical readers, but effective clinical experience is a valuable resource in this epidemic-ridden time. It is hoped that the operational details in this article will be helpful to clinicians as well as help readers who are not in the front line to understand a detailed way of thinking in medicine.

COVID-19 pneumonia, to the average person, is a sudden shock, and we are scrambling to learn the limited knowledge associated with it, to understand its complexity, to compete with its changes. We want scientists to give us the perfect answer, but for them, it's a big unknown that needs to be discovered and understood. This is a serious challenge to modern medicine. Medicine doesn't offer a cure all at once, but as long as we are honest about the unknown, share real experiences, and practice the scientific method under professional guidance, we will know the final answer.

Below is a dialogue between Wang Guangfa and people.

Wang was interviewed by people on the evening of Feb. 3, the fourth day after he recovered from COVID-19 pneumonia and the second day after returning to work at the hospital. As head of the Peking University First Hospital, he was initially cautious, saying he did not want to be interviewed again, but he was willing to talk to me about technical issues. He was willing to share his understanding of the sudden onset of the disease as a respiratory therapist, as well as a patient who had experienced COVID-19 pneumonia, as if facing an unknown Emerging Infectious Diseases, how do we recognize it, understand it, and deal with it? What is the scientific response?

Therefore, the writing of this article is also special. In this dialogue, we retain a large number of professor Wang Guangfa referred to the clinical experience, operational recommendations, diagnostic thinking. This may be tedious for non-medical readers, but effective clinical experience is a valuable resource in this epidemic-ridden time. It is hoped that the operational details in this article will be helpful to clinicians as well as help readers who are not in the front line to understand a detailed way of thinking in medicine.

COVID-19 pneumonia, to the average person, is a sudden shock, and we are scrambling to learn the limited knowledge associated with it, to understand its complexity, to compete with its changes. We want scientists to give us the perfect answer, but for them, it's a big unknown that needs to be discovered and understood. This is a serious challenge to modern medicine. Medicine doesn't offer a cure all at once, but as long as we are honest about the unknown, share real experiences, and practice the scientific method under professional guidance, we will know the final answer.

Below is a dialogue between Wang Guangfa and people.

By fei-ran Lee

Editor, sugar maple

People: When we talked to some of the doctors, they said that they were having a hard time with the criteria.

Wang Guangfa: Well, COVID-19 pneumonia is a disease, and suspected cases include signs of pneumonia. Although there are some mild cases, there are no signs of pneumonia, but most still have pneumonia. So with fever, cough, low white count, lymphocyte viral pneumonia, and an epidemiological history, we're looking at COVID-19 pneumonia.

People: That's the standard of suspicion.

Wang Guangfa: So to confirm the diagnosis, or the need for etiological testing. Etiological detection is now available in the form of PCR detection of nucleic acids or gene sequencing. But gene sequencing is characterized by high specificity and low sensitivity, so it is not practical in clinical practice. It is mainly used in the identification of particularly serious cases, such as the first case in each province to suggest gene sequencing to ensure that it must be tested for the virus. But at present, the most important clinical still is the PCR detection of nucleic acid. PCR itself, the current technology is more mature, many units if the laboratory conditions, do PCR is generally no problem.

People: But the clinician is now stuck with the nucleic acid test. When they actually operate nucleic acid testing, they encounter great difficulties, sometimes nucleic acid testing came out false negative, not measured, not measured, some need to repeat two or three times.

Wang Guangfa: ABOUT NUCLEIC ACID test negative problem, actually have a lot of technical level problem. For example, if you're sampling properly, that's sampling quality. In fact, we have some experience, is that you sample shallow, its positive rate is low. You have to go deep to get a sample, so the positive rate is probably high.

What do you mean by deep sampling? Is to use the throat swab when sampling, as deep as possible, pay special attention to dip in the amount of secretions. Because I personally experienced, I got sick when the nurse to my pick, pick very deep, pick I very uncomfortable, nausea, want to vomit, but I pick is positive. Throat swabs, the deeper the swab, the more uncomfortable the patient, so to tell the patient in advance, so that he has a psychological preparation, to obtain understanding.

Still some patients will have no phlegm, so the patient without phlegm may also have a lower respiratory viral load. At this time, you may consider using aerosolized inhalation. After aerosolized inhalation, you can retain sputum, it may also increase the accuracy of our tests. It is important to note that aerosolized inhalation is best done in a room alone, as this procedure may carry the virus, so it is not recommended in fever clinics where isolation measures are inadequate.

There are a lot of technical details that affect our tests, so the lab tests are not that simple.

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
NUCLEIC ACID test kit

People: a doctor mentioned that one of the most dangerous situations now is the nucleic acid test is negative, but the CT seems to be positive, is ground glass, and now the treatment is home observation.

Wang: I think for such patients, if there are clinical symptoms, imaging is consistent, although the laboratory test is negative, but I don't know how many times he did it, as if it was negative. This is really valuable for provinces that are still predominantly importing cases, because once you let a patient go, if he goes home and is not well isolated, and there is community transmission, then it is possible to convert the imported cases into local cases, if the local cases spread any further, it could be Kalanchoe Pinnata. If you can't control the Kalanchoe Pinnata, it's easy to see a second Wuhan. Therefore, from the point of view of prevention and control, if local admission capacity allows, the suspected cases of more stringent screening recommendations.

But like Wuhan area, is not quite same, because this kind of patient is too many. Now the problem I really understand, because that day I saw on TV, Wuhan Jinyintan Hospital do 300 specimens a day, to do more than 12 pm, the testing staff is very hard. What are we gonNA do about this? I think it's about technology, about innovation, about efficiency.

People: How do you do that?

Wang Guangfa: We want to do a study, which is a rapid detection method. It is a kind of bedside PCR, that is, PCR can be done beside the bed, which is a new trend in the development of laboratory medicine, it is now used to detect influenza (virus) . It's already on the market in the United States, and you can buy it in the supermarket. This bedside PCR flu test, which gives results in half an hour, is quick.

Because the State Food and Drug Administration requires clinical studies of this rapid diagnostic reagent, we were prepared to do clinical studies with our American partners, and then caught up with an epidemic, so I strongly recommend that partners work with us to develop a diagnostic method for the new coronavirus. I think it's really needed.

I saw that the partners provided me with information that was almost 95% diagnostic sensitivity and specificity for influenza viruses. This is a very high diagnostic efficiency, I think it is worth promoting. I suggested that they quickly develop a new rapid diagnostic method for coronavirus, and they've already said yes, so we want to work with them to get this up and running as soon as possible, to make a product that can push us to the front line, this is a good wish for us, these days I have been communicating this matter, hoping to be able to push this work a little faster.

Of course, there is a reasonable expectation that it will achieve 95% sensitivity and specificity as a flu virus test, but I'm not 100% sure it will achieve 95% sensitivity and specificity as a new virus. However, I think the chances of success are much faster and much better than if you were to start from scratch.

"people" : You mean this bedside PCR, like me, ordinary people, I go to the supermarket can also buy one, at home to test themselves?

Wang Guangfa: Yes, it is. It is approved in the United States and can be used not only in hospitals but also at home. Like a rapid diagnostic kit for flu, the flu now tests for antigens that you can actually do at home. Now, the problem is that the sensitivity is so low, that is, the test comes back positive and says yes, but the test comes back negative and you can't say no.

Like a cop catching a thief, I took the loot out of the thief's pocket, and I called him a thief. But someone suspected him of stealing it, and when I caught him, I didn't find any stolen goods on him, so as far as I'm concerned as a cop, I can't say he's not a thief, but I can't arrest him either.

People: How did you come up with this idea?

Wang Guangfa: People are now more concerned about saving patients, but in fact, a big bottleneck is whether we can quickly diagnose patients, quickly based on the diagnosis, to triage patients. If there is a very accurate, rapid diagnostic method, our efficiency will be greatly improved.

Because I was in Wuhan, the problem I saw was that many patients were overstocked in the fever clinic. There must be patients there, but there must also be patients who are not suffering from this disease. If they mix together, they will actually infect each other.

The experience of SARS, and this experience, I saw this phenomenon —— , that when a large number of patients come into a small space, and there's no way to separate them, to keep the space between them, then they all crowd together, the concentration of the virus is high, the doctor is also in, this time is prone to cross-infection. So I emphasize diagnosis, rapid diagnosis, rapid triage.

In addition, I see that Wuhan has built two hospitals and expanded a lot of wards, but it still does not seem to be able to meet the needs of patients. In fact, to improve the efficiency of the use of beds, the discharged patients should be discharged in time, but reliable testing methods should be available, to determine whether a patient should be discharged. Everyone goes to the CDC? It's not gonNA happen. Think of the pressure at a hospital like treasure lake, where they have to work until 12:00 to test 300 specimens a day. Therefore, we must now pay attention to the rapid development of rapid diagnostic methods, which are developed for rapid evaluation and evaluation, and are rapidly pushed to our front line for use, and rapidly relieve some of the pressure on the patients in front of us, i think that's the most important thing.

People: I understand that the approval and manufacturing process for this public health-related product can be quite long. So how long can a rapid-detection product, such as bedside PCR, be expected to land?

Wang Guangfa: I think the detection method is relatively simple, because it does not involve entering the human body, which can actually be very fast. We can test the specimen in clinical practice as long as we can prove its stability, feasibility in laboratory operation, and guarantee its quality control. If there is a certain gap, we will analyze under what circumstances we use it, and when we need to do PCR for verification, and this will have a very good effect, which is that we can greatly reduce the pressure of sending it to the laboratory, the pressure in the lab will be greatly reduced.

Of course, this rapid detection method also needs training, but because this is relatively simple, training up faster, then trained personnel will be more. It's true. We really, really need it.

People: How does this rapid detection work?

Wang: It's already patented, it's a mature technology, and the FDA has approved its use for influenza. It's actually a method. This product has a design, the design of the circuit, the design of the components, so that it is connected to the power supply, can automatically do analysis, this is its core technology. Why did I suggest it might be used for COVID-19 testing? Because the flu virus is testing its nucleic acid, and the COVID-19 is testing its nucleic acid, using a PCR technique, where I give you a template, and then I amplify it with polymerase, like a mold, a lot of bricks and tiles. If it turns out to be a chain, a chain I can not directly detect through the existing technology, but after amplification of dozens of cycles, may become a lot of the same nucleic acid chain, then re-detection is easy to detect. This technique is used for COVID-19, I'm just saying I gave it a different template. Give it the flu virus, it detects the flu virus; I give it COVID-19, it detects the COVID-19.

People: What is probably the most time-consuming aspect of this mature patented technology landing in China?

Wang Guangfa: I think we should make sure the experimental conditions are stable. This requires some clinical specimens for testing, so I suggest that they do this research in the country as soon as possible. Once it's done, the next step is to take it into a product, and put it into clinical trials, which we call clinical trials. After a clinical trial, compare the results with those of PCR to see how sensitive and specific it is. I think it would be nice to put it down to more than 80 percent, and if it could really go over 90 percent like the flu, that would be really useful for pandemic control, at least for classifying patients faster.

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
A staff member carries out nucleic acid detection image source CGTN press group video

People: The problem is that now, especially in Hubei, there are many patients who have difficulty in being diagnosed. One of their practical difficulties is that when suspicious..

Wang Guangfa: I know, it's just when you suspect something, you have to do a nucleic acid test, but you can't do a nucleic acid test, and then the patient is afraid to let go, so they're stuck in the fever clinic or the isolation ward, and then some new patients come in, and then, there's no room for admission. I understand. I know too well the current situation in Wuhan. Because when I was in Wuhan, I saw this sign in the fever clinic, and when the SARS epidemic broke out in Beijing, I really experienced the same situation first hand. At that time in the Peking University Hospital, the emergency room patients to the yard to get an IV, which means no admission, this patient how to do ah.

People: Medical Resources have been severely overloaded.

Wang Guangfa: Yes, in fact, from the experience of Beijing, it is an important link that has a great impact on the control of the epidemic. I think the situation in Wuhan is now past that stage, but it still faces similar problems.

People: So assuming this rapid detection method works, do we have a better buffer solution between now and when the new rapid detection method hits the ground?

Wang Guangfa: two factors affect the results of nucleic acid testing, one is the reagent, I am not a laboratory expert, I do not have too much say. But there are a number of technical operational points, do around the time to pay attention to these issues.

For example, we now find that some patients have upper-respiratory symptoms, sneezing, runny nose, so a nasal swab is more likely to be positive in this case. This has been proposed in the latest guidelines of the Ministry of Health, originally we wrote the pharynx swab, now we write the NASOPHARYNGEAL Swab, we have to determine the patient's symptoms.

At first we didn't really know the whole picture of the disease, and at that time we felt that nasal congestion, sneezing, and runny nose were not its characteristics, and I myself experienced a profound change in understanding when I got it. In theory, you should pick secretions from places that are seriously ill. But this is my personal experience, not a particularly rigorous study.

Another factor is the patient. For example, if a person has very mild symptoms at a very early stage of the disease and his viral load is low, the sample may not be detectable. For example, stay sputum sampling method, as far as possible deep cough stay sputum. Need special attention, do not leave phlegm in the enclosed space, should pay attention to the protection of other people. Like the time I left Phlegm in the night when I went outside to find a quiet place to cough deeply.

False negative, false positive, we can not completely avoid, so come across a negative result, we have to comprehensive analysis, take all the links into account, so as to reduce misjudgment. Our clinician will ask very carefully, you are upper respiratory symptoms mainly, or lower respiratory symptoms mainly, ask a little more detailed, this is very important. For example, if you can take a throat swab at the same time, or if you have sputum and take another sputum, the positive rate may be high.

From the clinical we keep specimens, in fact, there are some exquisite. The higher the sample level, the higher the positive rate of diagnosis.

PEOPLE: Today a doctor suggested that a very experienced doctor can see the difference in CT scans of the lungs. Can you add that to the diagnostic criteria, and run it against the nucleic acid test?

Wang Guangfa: that's not possible. Why not? Because there are many cases of pneumonia with similar symptoms, some viral pneumonia can be either this or ground glass, so it can not be used as a diagnostic criterion.

Lung CT is the standard of suspicion, you have imaging characteristics, classified as suspect, this is no problem, according to suspect isolation, screening, and even the appropriate treatment, it is no problem. But if you diagnose a patient based solely on imaging, there's a risk that you might diagnose an unrelated patient who isn't new pneumonia, mix it up with other patients and cross-infect them, and even if he isn't, eventually, it's GONNA be. This is not a good idea.

I understand why doctors make these recommendations, because they feel the tests are inadequate and stuck. I understand it, I understand it, I really do, so I'm really, really pushing it. I saw that some companies have already launched rapid diagnostic reagents, and I said, as soon as possible, these reagents, evaluation, evaluation really effective, quickly pushed to the front, really help our front-line medical personnel, some burden reduction.

People: can you tell by looking at your own lung films that it's new coronary pneumonia?

Wang Guangfa: I think my lung slices are very similar, but what is our general description of these lung slices? It's called Atypical pneumonia. It's got imaging features, low white count, low Rales in the lungs. The clinician's judgment, the judgment goes all the way to viral pneumonia, but whether it's the flu or the new coronavirus pneumonia, we actually don't know. This is also a knowledge popularization I want to do with you, in fact, the clinical doctor is not easy, he has a lot of clinical thinking, the average person is unable to understand.

In the past, some of our colleagues were experts who did not engage in clinical practice. They said, "how could you not recognize that SARS? "? You say yes, you say no, you say no. I explained to him that I could tell that it was a viral pneumonia, that it had an epidemiological history, and that the best I could do was to tell that it was an infectious viral pneumonia, and I couldn't go any further. Whether it's an Adenovirus, a flu virus, a SARS coronavirus, or something else, I don't know.

We clinical medicine is not one plus one equals two so simple, the clinician's judgment is sometimes really need the laboratory, it needs to consider many factors, to make a comprehensive judgment.

Wuhan Union Hospital

People: Does this mean, especially in the face of an unknown new disease, that the clinician's experience must ultimately fall on a etiological diagnosis like nucleic acid testing before it is finally stamped?

Wang: right, because we are now in a different era, like we diagnosed pneumonia decades ago, perhaps there is no way to do so many pathogen testing. There's a lot we can do now to find these infectious pneumonia.

People: But why is there such a cognitive gap now? On the one hand, I see that we have good technology, we have a kit, we have a good early warning system, but the results still look like when SARS?

Wang Guangfa: not the same, not the same, that obviously different. Now we basically have to diagnose based on nucleic acid test positive to determine, this and SARS really completely different at that time. And because I've been there twice, I feel strongly about that, because we have a different diagnosis, and this is a more accurate one.

The difference, however, is that this outbreak is not quite the same as SARS. During SARS, for example, I wouldn't say 100 percent, at least not for the most part, there were no hidden infections, or very mild infections, or even no hidden cases of symptoms. Although it is light, it is very significant in epidemiology, because it detoxifies, it detoxifies others also not alert, because no fever, it is very easy to spread. (Note: According to the fifth edition of the medical treatment plan of the HCHC, the main source of infection seen at present is patients with COVID-19 infection. Asymptomatic infection can also be a source of infection.in the case of SARS, we were really concerned about whether there were such patients, at least we haven't seen any definite cases.

What does this new coronavirus infection tell us about the number of mild cases? I think one of the important differences is that people with mild illness tend to be overlooked and spread the disease.

People: I was referring to the panic and confusion that people feel. It's the same thing.

Wang Guangfa: Panic, I think we were in Beijing at that time, Wuhan people can not feel. In fact, the situation in Beijing at that time and the situation in Wuhan were similar in terms of people's mentality. Everyone was more nervous and more fearful. This is understandable, because the epidemic was relatively serious, but in fact everyone should still have confidence. Our current prevention and control measures should be able to control the epidemic, but we need to be patient, need to wait for a period of time, our prevention and control of this effect to work, there is a certain delay. For example, I've got all the sick people in, but there are still patients out there who aren't sick, and they'll start to show up with the incubation period, and if we find all the sick people, then after 14 days there will be a significant decrease in new cases. Now, that's assuming, of course, that we take all the patients in, and it's difficult to see now, but you take most of the patients in, and it's good for the epidemic. With the expansion of the hospital, and went to a number of medical team members, we are still strengthening this strength, so I believe Wuhan will gradually go down, there is an inflection point, this is what we expect.

People: What do you make of this disease now? Now there is an emotion of confusion. Looking at the data now being released, on the one hand, we see that it is very strong, that there are more and more routes of transmission, that droplets, contacts, and now even doorknobs can be detected, but on the other hand, many of the symptoms of illness are mild, the national case fatality rate is less than 3% . Isn't this a bit like a bit of a bad flu?

Wang Guangfa: No, not like this, influenza light mortality, may feel nothing, generally less than 1% . The mortality rate is 1.4 to 16.7 per 100,000 people, but the total number of influenza cases is high and the population involved is particularly high. Its absolute number of deaths, at a glance, the world every year tens of thousands to one hundred thousand people ah, that is quite terrible. And now this epidemic, to now in Wuhan, the case-fatality rate is more than 3% , relatively speaking, the condition is quite serious. It is not said that the condition is serious, the condition is critical, the epidemic situation is serious, the station angle is different. I think we have to understand the disease scientifically, but it's not that simple.

PEOPLE: We should be wary of it because it's an unknown disease that we don't fully understand.

Wang Guangfa: Yes, it is a new disease, we are just beginning to understand it a little bit. What are we mostly afraid of? In case it has any more mutations. Like academician Zhong Nanshan, he had long suspected that there was a super spreader, just in case the gene gradually mutated, making it particularly susceptible to infection.

Why was there so much fear of a pandemic, the fact that there was a new flu in America that was much bigger than what we have now, that the overall case fatality rate was not high, but the impact was huge. The fear is that it's contagious, and if you combine it with what we call bird flu, the mortality rate in the highly pathogenic population is probably between 50 and 60 percent. It would be terrible if there were a disease that could spread like the flu and be as deadly as bird flu. So here's what we should be wary of.

But for now, it looks like the virus, at least, is less virulent and certainly less contagious than the flu.

People: if it were not for such an epidemic, what kind of disease would you be focusing on at this time of winter?

Wang Guangfa: I specialize in difficult and serious diseases in this department in the hospital, but because many of us are out-of-town patients, at this stage, fewer patients come to see me. We're all working now. I'm already working. In fact, we are going to send a medical team to support Wuhan again. We already have two groups of medical team members. The two deputy directors of our department are already in Wuhan. Our Dean is also in Wuhan. Work is still going on at home (Beijing) , but we are ready to send personnel to the Wuhan Front at any time. Because the epidemic situation is quite tense, yesterday the Health Committee held a discussion of the fifth version of the treatment program, I went out yesterday for a meeting. Because some of them are in Wuhan, like Academician Zhong in Guangzhou, and the majority of the Expert Group are also in Beijing. We are having a video conference and meeting many old friends, academician Zhong, academician Wang Chen and academician Li Lanjuan. We are all very happy, and they're glad I got out so quickly. In addition, we are also shouldering Beijing's epidemic prevention and control, the pressure is also considerable.

People: In terms of medical statistics, what are the signs and what are the signs that we can come out and see each other?

Wang Guangfa: I think this time may also be a bit longer, at least we should see the inflection point of the epidemic. What is the inflection point of the epidemic? We're still seeing more new cases, and then, one day, we're seeing fewer new cases, and that's when we hit the tipping point. When are we GONNA BE SAFE? We're seeing the new cases go away, and that's when it's safe to say. If you look at the daily number, it helps to judge the epidemic. But the trend of the epidemic has something to do with whether our measures are in place or not, the movement of social population, etc. . Many factors determine the trend of the epidemic, and it is difficult to draw a definite conclusion when the epidemic can be completely controlled. I would also like to say that the individual is our most important line of defense against disease. The government is responsible, our various medical institutions are responsible, but ultimately it has to come down to the individual. Responsibility for one's health is the last line of Defense.
